editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Rector and Fellows of Exeter College.

msDesc.head: Statutes of Edward III, in French; England, s. xv1

msItem.incipit: Compotus Johannis Kolne Messor Johannes Michel apud brenn a festo Pascalis anno regni regis Ricardi II post conquestum tercio
msItem.note: The entries include the names Stephen de Bernham and Robert Crouch which, together with the mention of Colne, a common name in Essex, and Ipswich, on the Essex-Suffolk border (see History below), suggest a connection with that area.

msItem.title: Statutes, 1–50 Edward III (1327–77)
msItem.incipit: Le statut lez Dispensers fait a primer parlement apres le corounement. Come Hugh le Dispenser le Piere et Hugh le Dispenser le fitz
msItem.note: pr. SR i. 251–396. Through the loss of the next quire our text ends in 50 Edward III ch. 3, SR i. 396b/20 (with catchword ‘parmy lez guerrez’).

supportDesc.extent:
128 leaves preceded and followed by one medieval membrane flyleaf 193 52
120 85–90
supportDesc.collation: 1–168. Catchwords by the scribe. No quire numbers or signatures.

layoutDesc.layout: One column, 27 lines. Ruled in crayon across full sheet.

handDesc.handNote: A good mixed anglicana (d, e, r, s) and secretary (a, g, s) hand, legal in character, punctuated by occasional punctus elevatus.

decoDesc.decoNote: None. Spaces with guide letters for initials remain blank.

binding.p: Sewn on two bands in a stiff membrane cover with two green ribbon ties on each cover. The flyleaves (fols. i, I) are a single sheet wrapped round the spine.

history.provenance: Unknown before the 17th century, but see item *1 above.

Among the many pen-trials on the flyleaves are (fol. 1r) ‘Willelmus Fall de Gippinwic’, s. xivin, which, if the place-name means Ipswich, may suggest that the book has an Essex connection, and (fol. ir) ‘Vinter(?) Vyner [or ‘Varners’] de Wilsingham’, s. xiv. ‘Godefreidus Haukyn’, fol. iv, s. xv2, may be an owner’s name.

On fol. 1r ‘96’ and ‘Statuta Regni ad an. 1 Ed. III ad 46 Ed: III, vide Cat. MSS Glynne Barti’ and the same number on both the spine and the front cover, refer to the catalogue of the library of Sir William Glynne (CMA ii. 49–54, no. 2020. 96), with the majority of whose manuscripts the book came to Exeter by bequest of Joseph Sandford: see MS 87, History.
Exeter library identifications are a label inside the front cover, on which are ‘Exeter’, ‘Coxe CLXVII’ (also on the outer front cover) and the book stamp.

source.bibl: Andrew G. Watson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Exeter College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press), 2000.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Exeter College Library.
